unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, I've been meaning to share something that's been on my mind, especially since graduation season is basically upon us. It’s about all those fancy degrees and certificates we work so hard to get.
normalised: Hey everyone! So, I've been meaning to share something that's been on my mind, especially since graduation season is basically upon us. It’s about all those fancy degrees and certificates we work so hard to get.

unnormalised: It's awesome to see everyone with their shiny new achievements, right? Like, congrats to Aisha Khan who just received her Ph.D. from JNU! And kudos to Rohan Sharma for acing his Class 12 exams with a whopping 98% from DPS, R.K. Puram. Seriously impressive stuff!
normalised: It's awesome to see everyone with their shiny new achievements, right? Like, congrats to Aisha Khan who just received her P-h-D from J-N-U! And kudos to Rohan Sharma for acing his Class twelve exams with a whopping ninety eight percent from D-P-S, R-K Puram. Seriously impressive stuff!

unnormalised: But I've been thinking lately, what do these "Dr.", "B.Tech," "MBA" titles really *mean* in the long run? Does having a "B.A. Hons" automatically make you smarter or more successful than someone who didn’t have the opportunity to pursue it? I'm not so sure.
normalised: But I've been thinking lately, what do these "Doctor", "B-Tech," "M-B-A" titles really mean in the long run? Does having a "B-A Honors" automatically make you smarter or more successful than someone who didn’t have the opportunity to pursue it? I'm not so sure.

unnormalised: My cousin, for example, has an "M.Com" from Mumbai University. Sounds impressive, doesn’t it? But honestly, he’s been struggling to find a job that matches his qualifications for ages. Whereas, my auto-rickshaw driver, Raju bhai, never even finished Class 10, but he knows more about the city, people and life hacks than anyone I know!
normalised: My cousin, for example, has an "M-Com" from Mumbai University. Sounds impressive, doesn’t it? But honestly, he’s been struggling to find a job that matches his qualifications for ages. Whereas, my auto-rickshaw driver, Raju bhai, never even finished Class ten, but he knows more about the city, people and life hacks than anyone I know!

unnormalised: It’s not to discredit anyone’s hard work, not at all. Getting a "M.Sc." or a "PGDM" takes serious dedication and effort. But sometimes, I feel we put *too* much emphasis on these pieces of paper. We think a "Cert. in Data Science" guarantees a great career, or that a "Diploma in Engg." is the only path to success.
normalised: It’s not to discredit anyone’s hard work, not at all. Getting a "M-Sc." or a "P-G-D-M" takes serious dedication and effort. But sometimes, I feel we put too much emphasis on these pieces of paper. We think a "Certificate in Data Science" guarantees a great career, or that a "Diploma in Engineering" is the only path to success.

unnormalised: The real world is messy, complicated, and rarely fits neatly into a curriculum. Having a "BE" from IIT-Bombay is amazing, but it doesn't teach you resilience, or how to handle failures, or how to connect with people. Those skills often come from experiences outside the classroom.
normalised: The real world is messy, complicated, and rarely fits neatly into a curriculum. Having a "B-E" from I-I-T-Bombay is amazing, but it doesn't teach you resilience, or how to handle failures, or how to connect with people. Those skills often come from experiences outside the classroom.

unnormalised: So, let's celebrate the "MBBS", the "LLB", and all the other letters after people’s names. But let's also remember that they're just *one* part of the story. Someone who holds the title of “CA” isn’t necessarily better than another; its about how they apply their knowledge.
normalised: So, let's celebrate the "M-B-B-S", the "L-L-B", and all the other letters after people’s names. But let's also remember that they're just one part of the story. Someone who holds the title of “C-A” isn’t necessarily better than another; its about how they apply their knowledge.

unnormalised: Ultimately, it’s about what you *do* with what you know, not just what's written on your certificate. And maybe, just maybe, we should give a bit more respect to the Raju bhais of the world too, the ones who are constantly learning and growing, even without those fancy titles. Food for thought, eh?
normalised: Ultimately, it’s about what you do with what you know, not just what's written on your certificate. And maybe, just maybe, we should give a bit more respect to the Raju bhais of the world too, the ones who are constantly learning and growing, even without those fancy titles. Food for thought, eh?
